author: Agenzia ANSA
title: La Terra si prepara all'arrivo di una forte tempesta solare - Spazio e Astronomia - Ansa.it
text:
Una forte tempesta solare sta per investire la Terra e gli effetti più importanti sono previsti nella giornata di sabato 11. Il Centro di previsione meteorologica spaziale dell'agenzia statunitense Noaa ha aumentato il livello previsto per la tempesta a quello G4, il secondo più alto sulla scala, che prevede impatti sulla rete elettrica, sui sistemi di navigazione satellitare come il Gps e problemi a satelliti e veicoli spaziali, oltre alla maggiore probabilità di poter ammirare le aurore boreali anche a basse latitudini.
"La tempesta potrà iniziare già oggi e proseguirà poi nella giornata di domani", dice all'ANSA Mauro Messerotti, docente di Meteorologia spaziale all'Università di Trieste. "Ma l'attività solare si manterrà intensa anche nel prossimo periodo, ci stiamo avvicinando al picco". L'ultima tempesta G4 si è verificata infatti meno di due mesi fa, il 23 marzo 2024.
Una tempesta solare, o geomagnetica, è un disturbo del campo magnetico terrestre, colpito dalle particelle ad alta energia emesse dal Sole che rendono elettricamente carico lo strato più esterno dell'atmosfera. A causa di questo fenomeno, le onde radio che viaggiano in queste zone perdono energia a causa di collisioni più frequenti con gli elettroni, e ciò ne causa il degrado o anche il completo assorbimento.
La tempesta in arrivo si deve all'intensa attività di un gigantesco gruppo di macchie solari, chiamato AR3664, che si estende per circa 200.000 chilometri, dunque 16 volte circa le dimensioni della Terra. Si tratta di una delle regioni più grandi e attive osservate in questo ciclo solare, che è iniziato nel dicembre 2019. "La regione è caratterizzata da una grande complessità, con campi magnetici molto intensi che causano una situazione particolarmente instabile. È così grande - dice Messerotti - che è visibile anche ad occhio nudo, ovviamente sempre con un'adeguata protezione".
La macchia solare AR3664, confrontata con le dimensioni della Terra (fonte: Mauto Messerotti, Università di Triste)
Nel frattempo anche gli astrofili si sono mobilitati per fotografare il fenomeno, come Franco Fantasia del Gruppo Astrofili Palidoro, che è riuscito a catturare un'immagine dell'enorme gruppo di macchie solari.
Il gruppo di macchie solari AR3664 (fonte: Franco Fantasia, Gruppo Astrofili Palidoro)
L'estensione di AR3664 è confrontabile a quella di un altro enorme gruppo di macchie solari, quello di Carrington, che fece sentire pesantemente i suoi effetti tra agosto e settembre 1859: durante quel periodo, la regione emise una serie di potenti brillamenti solari (violente eruzioni che sprigionano un'energia equivalente a varie decine di milioni di bombe atomiche) ed espulsioni di massa coronale, le cosiddette Cme (espulsioni di materia sotto forma di plasma), che provocarono incendi negli uffici del telegrafo e innescarono aurore vicino all'equatore.
Negli ultimi giorni il gruppo di macchie solari AR3664 ha emesso diversi potenti brillamenti solari: nella giornata del 9 maggio, in particolare, ne ha prodotti due di classe X, la più elevata, rilevati dal satellite Goes-16 di Nasa e Noaa alle ore italiane 11,13 e 19,44. A entrambi questi eventi sono associate le due espulsioni di massa coronale che stanno viaggiando verso il nostro pianeta. A queste si aggiungono tre Cme generate tra l'8 e il 9 maggio, il cui arrivo è sempre previsto entro l'11 maggio. "In tutto, cinque Cme sono dirette verso la Terra", conferma Messerotti: "Nel caso in cui si fondano tra loro, questo ovviamente renderà la tempesta geomagnetica ancora più intensa, ma è impossibile prevederlo".

author: @PenDailyNews
title: PREP BASEBALL, SOFTBALL: Riders' Politika, DeLeon fire 2-hitter at North Mason | Peninsula Daily News
text:
PORT ANGELES — The Port Angeles baseball team won its Olympic League opener 8-0 over North Mason, getting a combined two-hitter from pitchers Rylan Politika and Bryce DeLeon and big games from Kody Williams and Nathan Basden.
Politika started Tuesday’s game at Civic Field and gave up a double to the second batter he faced. From that point on, he was perfect, not allowing another hit or a walk over the next 3⅔ innings while striking out five.
DeLeon came in to pitch in the fifth and was just as strong, giving up one hit and one walk in three innings. He struck out three. DeLeon also made a couple of great defensive plays, quickly pouncing on a pair of good bunts by North Mason hitters and throwing them out at first.
“Rylan and Bryce put in a lot of work this offseason in the weight room and it shows,” said coach Zac Moore.
Politika said he just threw strikes. “I know I have a good defense behind me,” he said.
The Riders also scored seven of their runs in the first two innings and then let Politika and DeLeon cruise to the seventh.
“It’s easy to pitch with a big lead,” Politika said. “They gave me a lot of insurance runs.”
At the plate, Basden was 2-for-3 with three RBIs. He hit a two-run double in the first inning to get the Roughriders’ on the board.
Williams, taking over this season at first base, was 2-for-4 with two runs scored and an RBI. Luke Flodstrom was 3-for-4, while pinch-runner Hunter Stratford had a stolen base and scored three runs. Josiah Gooding at third base also made a great diving catch in foul territory of a pop up.
The Riders bounced back after an 11-1 nonleague loss to Ingraham this weekend played in soggy conditions. Though the game was played in heavy rain, “we want to be able to play in those conditions,” Moore said. By comparison, Tuesday night’s game at Civic Field was near-perfect conditions for mid-March and it showed with the Riders making zero errors.
Port Angeles (1-0, 1-1) played at North Mason on Wednesday in a home-and-away league series, then will host Nathan Hale at Civic Field at 4:15 p.m. Friday. That game may be moved to Volunteer Field if the weather is poor. The Port Angeles JV will play at Forks at 5 p.m. today.
Port Angeles 8, North Mason 0
NM 0 0 0 0 0 0 — 0 2 4
PA 4 3 0 1 0 0 — 8 10 0
Pitching
PA — Politika 4 IP, H, 5 K; DeLeon 3 IP, H, BB, 3 K.
Hitting
PA — Basden 2-3, 2B, 3 RBI; Williams 2-4, 2 R, RBI; Flodstrom 3-4; Stratford 3 R, SB; Angeveine 1-3, R, BB.
Kingston 3, Sequim 2
KINGSTON — Sequim and Kingston battled in a scoreless game until the sixth inning when the Buccaneers plated three runs in the bottom of the sixth to pull out a 3-2 season-opening victory.
Ethan Staples started for the Wolves and pitched great, going four scoreless innings, allowing five hits and no walks. He struck out seven. Bryant Laboy pitched 1⅓ innings, allowing just one hit, but two earned runs. He struck out two. Braydan White pitched the final two-thirds of an inning, allowing an unearned run on two hits. He struck out one.
The Wolves managed just three hits. White had a single in the sixth and Lincoln Bear was hit by a pitch. Devyn Dearinger singled to drive in White, and Bear was able to come around to score on an error as the Wolves took a 2-0 lead.
But they weren’t able to hold it. Kingston scored three in the bottom of the sixth on a walk, stolen base, two singles and an error. The Wolves were three up, three down in the top of the seventh.
Sequim (0-1, 0-1) hosted Kingston on Wednesday in an away-and-home series, then hosts Nathan Hale at 11 a.m. Saturday.
Kingston 3, Sequim 2
Seq. 0 0 0 0 0 2 0 — 2 3 1
K’ston 0 0 0 0 0 3 x — 3 8 2
Pitching
Sequim — Staples 4 IP, 5 H, 7 K; Laboy 1.1 IP, H, 2 ER, BB, 2 K; White 0.2 IP, 2 H, K.
Hitting
Sequim — White 1-3, R; Bear 1-2, R, HBP; Dearinger 1-2, RBI, BB.
Girls Softball Forks 12, Port Angeles JV 5 Forks 18, Port Angeles JV 11
FORKS — The Forks softball team picked up a pair of victories over the Port Angeles JV squad 12-5 and 18-11, with Chloe Gaydeski having an especially big day.
In the opener, Gaydeski pitched the entire seven innings, striking out 14, while allowing two earned runs on four hits. In the nightcap, she was 2-for-2 with a double, a triple, four RBIs and two runs scored.
Bailey Johnson also had a big day, going 3-for-5 in the two games with a double, a home run, five runs scored and three RBIs.
In the opening game, Avery Dilley was 2-for-3 with a double and a triple, a run scored and five RBIs.
In the nightcap, eighth-grader Brooklyn Rondeau was 3-for-3 with two RBIs and a run scored. Fynlie Peters and Kendyl Woody each hit a double.
For the Port Angeles JV, Lilly Anne Lancaster was 2-for-3 in the opening game, while Adison Richard had a double in the nightcap. Juno Rognlien had a hit and three runs scored in the second game.
Forks (4-0) next plays at Chief Leschi on Tuesday.

author: Rajesh Mazumder
title: FITUR Cruises 2025 Showcases Global Cruise Industry Growth and Trends with Over 37 Million Passengers Expected
text:
The FITUR Cruises event, a dedicated space for cruise tourism at the International Tourism Fair organized by IFEMA MADRID, is being held from January 22 to 26. This year, it has placed a spotlight on the growing popularity of cruises worldwide, with industry forecasts projecting over 37 million passengers embarking on cruise vacations in 2025.
Experts in the sector highlighted that while cruise passengers remain loyal to the experience, they are often eager to explore different shipping companies, embracing new styles and offerings.
Engaging Activities and Industry Insights FITUR Cruises featured an array of activities and presentations for professionals and the general public, analyzing the latest developments and future trends. At the Cruise Campus, an innovative platform offered engaging talks and events, presenting the world of cruises from diverse perspectives. This included revealing key data on industry advancements and insights for both shipping companies and travelers.
Notable presentations included UCM professor Frank Babingerse discussing challenges facing cruise ports and Baluma Cruises, representing Celebrity Cruises and Azamara, showcasing the unique aspects of premium cruise lines. Costa Cruises introduced its 2025 offerings, emphasizing its “All Inclusive” packages, while organizing networking events for travel agents.
Understanding the Modern Cruise Passenger Jesús García, editor-in-chief of Cruceroadicto.com , provided an in-depth analysis of the 2025 cruise passenger profile. According to García, cruise travelers are increasingly discerning, prioritizing sustainability, slow travel, and last-minute getaways. Preferences include departures within three hours of home, flexible schedules to avoid overcrowding, and options for “workations.”
In another session, Emerald Spanic presented strategies for effectively marketing luxury cruises, offering valuable tips to travel agents catering to this high-end segment.
Upcoming Events at FITUR Cruises The event’s packed schedule includes discussions on redefining ultra-premium cruises, the appeal of Spanish-language cruise excursions, and practical travel tips. Additionally, the Cruise Scavenger Hunt, sponsored by Intermundial, will invite participants to solve clues across FITUR pavilions, with prizes such as cruises for two, excursion vouchers, and travel insurance.
Leading Cruise Lines in Attendance FITUR Cruises 2025 boasts participation from major shipping companies, including Costa Cruises (Italy), Baluma Cruises (representing Celebrity Cruises and Azamara from the US), and NCL Holding, which represents Norwegian Cruise Line, Oceania Cruises, and Regent Seven Seas (all from the US). Emerald Spanic, representing Emerald Cruises and Scenic Luxury Cruises (Australia), along with Shore2Shore, specializing in Spanish-language excursions, are also present.
Celebrating Excellence: Cruceroadicto Awards FITUR Cruises hosted the third edition of the Cruceroadicto Awards, where travelers selected the best shipping companies, ships, and ports of 2024 across 16 categories. Highlights include:
Best Port in Asia : Yokohama Best Atlantic Port in Europe : Lisbon Best Caribbean Port : San Juan, Puerto Rico Best Mediterranean Port : Barcelona Best North American Port : Miami Best Global Baseport : Barcelona Best Family Ship : MSC World Europa Best Premium Shipping Company : Celebrity Cruises The event has successfully showcased the vibrancy and innovation within the cruise industry, setting the stage for continued growth and evolution in 2025 and beyond.
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->business reporting and performance
Economy, Business and Finance->tourism and leisure industry

author: David Jurado
title: La familia del soldado ahogado en Córdoba se querellará contra la cadena de mando
text:
La familia de
uno de los dos militares fallecidos en el transcurso de unas maniobras en la base militar de Cerro Muriano presentará una querella contra la cadena de mando por las presuntas negligencias que, a su parecer, se produjeron y que tuvieron como resultado el fallecimiento de dos militares y la evacuación a un centro hospitalario de otros dos por una hipotermia. Así lo ha avanzado Cadena Ser Córdoba. Se trata de los familiares del soldado Carlos León, que perdió la vida ahogado en un lago junto al cabo Miguel Ángel Jiménez.
El abogado Luis Romero, contratado por la familia de León, ha informado a Diario CÓRDOBA, del grupo Prensa Ibérica, de que mañana presentará la querella "contra toda la cadena de mando", que incluye al capitán de los ejercicios donde fallecieron los soldados, y que ya ha sido retirado del mando, así como "al teniente coronel y el general de la brigada", tal y como ha apuntado el doctor en derecho penal.
De igual modo, también se querellarán contra el
[Ministerio de Defensa](/tags/ministerio-de-defensa/) como responsable civil subsidiario.
Romero ha informado de que la familia de Carlos León "quiere llegar hasta el fondo de este asunto" y de que van a "intervenir en todos los frentes legales" para que el caso no se cierre en falso bajo ninguna circunstancia.
En cuanto a si los familiares del cabo Miguel Ángel Jiménez realizarán los mismos pasos o se sumarán a la querella, Romero ha indicado que no le consta que hayan dado ningún paso en ese sentido.
Por último, el abogado ha informado de que la familia de Carlos León ya se ha personado en el procedimiento como acusación particular en las diligencias previas.

author: Joseph Halm
title: Mandeville's Sheppard picks Duke as part of 5-person signing class | <span class=
text: Mandeville running back Nate Sheppard made it official. After his season ended abruptly with a Week 8 leg injury, the senior turned the page and signed his letter of intent to play at Duke during a five-person signing ceremony at Mandeville on Dec. 5. “Today means a lot to me,” Sheppard said. “I’ve been ready to get up to Duke really since the injury. I love being around my teammates, but once I got injured, I was just thinking about how could I get back on the field and play.” The 5-foot-10, 190-pound athlete is still wheeling around on his scooter after successful surgery weeks ago, but that didn’t dampen the mood Thursday. Sheppard, who committed to the Blue Devils in August, said he never waived from Duke. “Being a new coaching staff, this was their first full recruiting class of high school players, so being part of that experience and being a part of this high school class that will be the foundation of the new Duke program is pretty special,” he said. The final numbers for his senior season were impressive — 1,888 yards from scrimmage with a 269.7 yards per game average. He finished with 26 offensive touchdowns and 31 total trips to the end zone. Mandeville coach Craig Jones said those numbers only tell part of the story. “I think he is going to be an instant contributor on special teams, and he’ll fight for playing time in the backfield. He’s a competitor, and he wants to win. He brought in what we were doing offensively really fast. I expect he’ll do the same at Duke,” Jones said. “His football IQ is much higher than what you get with your average high school football player. He’s going to be able to step in at the college level right away. They are much more detailed, with more options for anything that they do. He’ll be able to jump in and contribute right away. He’s going to know all of his assignments.” Sheppard, who plans to enroll in January, said he’s ready for the next chapter. “Getting that extra experience around the staff, around the coaches and getting the playbook six months earlier than everybody else is definitely an advantage,” Sheppard said. “It was really important to me to get up there early. I’ve been wanting to be a mid-year enrollee for the last year. I just want to get familiar with the program as soon as possible.” Sheppard shared the stage with four of his classmates. Max Jacketti will run track and cross country at Division II Mississippi College in Clinton, Miss. The four-year letterman in track and cross country, who set several school records, said the Choctaws will give him a chance to compete at a high level. “Coach (Chris) Weber really made it feel like home,” Jacketti said. “I also want to compete at the national level for D-II. They just got back from nationals and had a good performance. I feel like it’s a really good place for me to excel and get to the times that I want to get to.” Evan Hasenkampf will swim at Division III College of Wooster in Wooster, Ohio. Hasenkampf started swimming at age 5 and was a four-year swimmer for the Skippers. At Wooster, Hasenkampf said he’ll swim the 500-yard, 1000-yard and mile strokes as his main distances. “They had everything that I was looking for,” Hasenkampf said. “The academics at the school are great. When I visited, it felt like home. They were really interested in me, and that kind of put them over the edge.” A pair of baseball players also signed as outfielder Tyler Fischer is headed to Delgado while Logan McNamara will play at Division III Belhaven in Jackson, Miss. Fischer, who hit .330 last season and led the team in RBIs and doubles, said staying close to home was important. “It just felt like a good fit for me,” Fischer said. “It’s close to home. I felt like it was important to stay close to my family and still get to play college baseball. McNamara said the Blazers felt like a perfect fit to continue his pitching career. “Once I went on my visit, it just felt like home,” McNamara said. “The coaches treated me well. The coaches knew what they were talking about, and I feel like the program can help me grow as a person. I feel like I’ll have really good success there.”
